text: [Applause] thank you and good morning good morning we by because one
of the things that we need to build Innovation is a great deal of spirit and
energy so I want you to join me in that spirit and energy so there will be a few
things that are a little different about the talk this morning first of all it's
a PowerPoint free zone no PowerPoint
secondly even though we always ask people to turn off their cell phones if
any of you are on Twitter and want to tweet while I'm talking please feel free
as long as you don't take business calls we all have to learn the new media and I
love the fact that it spreads our message worldwide and I am going to talk in a
little slightly different way about Innovation because there are
paradoxes in business life and one Paradox is
that we talk about certain Concepts but don't demonstrate them I used to define
participation for example remember participative management
participation was what the top ordered the middle to do for the
bottom Innovation is another one of those
Concepts that we invoke and and yet don't practice I'm asked by many
companies to come and talk to them about how they can get more Innovation and their first question
is who else is doing it or I'm told they want more
Innovation they just don't want to be the first so I decided that I should talk
about innovation in a way at least at the beginning that's a little more creative if we want creativity if we
want ideas then we have to be more engaging and more creative in the ways
we talk about those ideas but I like the word
gamechanging because for a number of years I've been thinking that if we want
to unlock creativity we need to engage in in more
imaginative thinking so I often ask Business Leaders to think about their
industry or their company in terms of a game or a sport if we're going to be
game changing we'd better know what game we're playing so I asked people to think about
that question what game are you playing what's a good metaphor or image for the
game your company or your industry is engaged in one of my favorite metaphors I returned
to from years ago is that the game we're playing and why in Ovation is so
critical and what the traps are as well as the possibilities the game we're playing is
like the croquet game in Alice and Wonderland in that game everything is
alive everything is moving around the players nothing is stable so goes to hit
the ball but the Mallet she's using is a flamingo and just when she's about to
hit the ball the flamingo lifts its head and looks in another Direction which I think is a perfect
image for technology for the tools we use they are changing so
rapidly that we have to have a different approach to how we lead and where we
look for ideas about the future future the tools are changing so fast that they
both provide an opportunity for innovators and a challenge for everybody
that wants to keep up with change and so technology and the tools are changing so
quickly it means there's a premium on knowledge in every Enterprise and that
often means knowledge that's coming from unexpected places well outside the
center and often from below and that's a tremendous change and
one we have to tap if we want more innovation in companies or in
countries Innovation can come at any age we can have brainstorms at any age but
we do know that certain things happen to people as they advance in their
careers that sometimes becomes an innovation trap it cuts off the capacity
to support the new so I know that one of the things that people get as they advance in their
careers not just Privileges and perquisites and maybe a little bit more
money but one of the things they get is that they earn the right to never talk
to anybody who disagrees with them Yes Minister Yes
Minister well inovation thrives on
dissent Innovation thrives on people who say you're wrong on people who say
there's a different way there's a better way conventional wisdom doesn't guide us
appropriately into the future we want to know that it's safe that somebody else has done it first but
Innovation require requires the courage to have a conversation about
things that are different and in organizations or countries that
respect the hierarchy of tradition often it's more difficult for
new ideas to surface in a way that makes a tremendous difference it also thrives
on new knowledge as I said earlier and the other thing that comes with the
privilege of a career and in established organizations this is especially true is
that people eventually rise to a position where they never have to learn
anything again they never have to learn anything again they have the answers and coming
with their position should be the answers and yet in this Alice and
Wonderland croquet game world and remember we're still just talking about that moving Flamingo where our tools
keep facing in other directions who are the first people you know to use the new
tools new people new users are often the source of knowledge and learning in this
world of rapidly changing technology but one of the Innovation traps is the
assumption that all good ideas come at the top that people at the top of
organizations or in countries are smart enough to figure out where the future is going and therefore to
bet on the Industries or tell people in the company
what to work on but it is true that people who are newer who are below who are peripheral
often have good ideas innovators learn from jarring new experiences that
challenge their own assumptions the Trap is to decide that all the science can be
done right here here in our own Laboratories and sure science is pretty
Universal but innovators get their ideas and see them in use often because
of the jarring experiences that come from a
discontinuous experience of something that's different from what they all already thought and
that's just as true of the new users of the young of the new in organizations
most companies of any size bring in new people and yet never
learn from them new people often look at old products with fresh eyes and yet our
goal when bringing new people into our Enterprises is to teach them what we
know rather than hear what they think about what we
know and there are new modes now coming into being in organizations however that
seek high levels of innovation and one is self-organizing
from below the Innovation trap as I said is insular
thinking that assumes all wisdom resides at the top all wisdom resides at the
center and it only resides within our industry or our company and the lesson the enduring
lesson is innovation thrives where there's diversity descent new learning
and where the young can teach the old whenever organizations or people can
tap the wisdom of the young it's why I love some of what intertrade island is
doing is absolutely the right thing the University students getting students and young people to build businesses as
quickly as they can you can acquire them you can sub invest in them but the
energy that's required for Innovation and the ability to look at things with
fresh eyes that's where you get Innovation that's the source of strength
for the future and we can all cultivate that in ourselves as long as we don't find
ourselves and our organizations falling into the Trap of becoming
insular headquarters Centric and hierarchical in our

up walks to another part of the court and sits down again I think that's a
perfect metaphor for our customers for the people we're trying to

they're not just lying there rolled up in a ball waiting for us to hit them
with our latest offering they have minds of their own
and they're going to move to find the best and most
satisfying and in fact they do it as a matter of course this has been a global
Trend the fickle customer the demanding customer this trend means that companies
are forced to innovate like it or not in part because the competition is doing it
and the best way to stay ahead of the competition is to innovate one step

Advantage you have a Monopoly you have a temporary
Monopoly Innovation produces a temporary Monopoly and you know if you get too

Innovation is of course the way that one stays ahead of the customer but the Trap

how different from what the established Pathways already
permit so I'm going to tell you another little funny story I hope it's
funny um and I'm telling you funny stories by the way because as I said
Innovation is about thinking differently and I'll tell you a story when I end about that so this story comes from one
of my favorite management philosophers Woody Allen
I see you've heard of him I'm glad so Woody Allen wrote a story in which he
was imagining the first landing of aliens from another planet on
Earth the first real UFO landing and he said when most of us
imagine the landing of aliens from another planet we imagine well like we
used to say in the US about the Japanese are coming now we say the Chinese are coming they're going to buy everything
they're going to take us over so in his story he said most of us worry about the
landing of a UFO that is light years away it's centuries ahead of us in
technology so it's going to invade and take us over because we won't know how
to communicate with them we won't understand what they're doing and so
they'll just take over and he said in the story that what
worried him was not light years away or centuries ahead what worried
him was the aliens who would land from another planet and be just 15 minutes
ahead because if they were just 15 minutes ahead they'd never be late for a meeting
they'd always be first to get the best retail space they would be their first
when the stock market opened you know they would get it all just by 15 minutes
and I thought that's really very profound as I was studying Innovation
it's the 15minute competitive Advantage not necessarily the long-term bet on a
future science that's untested well in Massachusetts we have a thriving biotechnology industry
except that it is so longterm it's not making money for anybody and it's great
to have some things that are so long term but you can really because you know
the payback Horizons are a long time from certain science-based industries
and those are wonderful and they may pay off in a very big way but that's not
what our economy is resting on it's resting on lots and lots of business
startups it's vesting on many Technologies many ideas that are fresh
ideas many of them started by young people the 15minute competitive Advantage can be as
important or more important than the 15-year competitive
Advantage so what we need is the ability to turn fast have long-term thinking but
shortterm wins and that's what customers want customers aren't going to wait 15 years
for your next gr offering they want it now major tra in Innovation is waiting for the
Blockbuster waiting for something so dramatically new and different first of
all it might take a long time and placing all your bets just on a Blockbuster on some Grand technology and
that's where all the bets go in the country or on some some great new
blockbuster product so Innovation is a constant
process it's one that doesn't simply involve finding a blockbuster so far
ahead that you'll steal a march on the competition but as long as you innovate
you do have what economists call a temporary Monopoly that is customers
will flow to you because you're the only one that has it and so that question
that I got that I said in the beginning about Innovation who else is doing it
well you want no one else to do it in order to be unique and have the
